body: Mhm there is a short phase at the end when effectively one thread is used, I think this is testing, I ll add some extra flags to check.
Testing is not within tensorflow, so that would be expected.
So this is not testing because testing is only triggered once you use calls that require p-values on the output object on de.test.wald().

Which test is it exactly?
Between two fittings there can be some time necessary to re-construct the Tensorflow graph

So this happens in Estimator.finalizer() in the line store = XArrayEstimatorStore(self), so likely this is hessian computation which should dominate the run time of this step. This also occurs if I set:
os.environ.setdefault("TF_LOOP_PARALLEL_ITERATIONS", "2")
which should allow tf.map_fn to parallelize the mapping of the hessian across genes, which is odd. I also saw newton-rhapson using only one core during training, this is almost surely related.
Have you been able to recreate the single-thread bottleneck behaviour?

actually TF_LOOP_PARALLEL_ITERATIONS is 10 per default.
Thats really strange:
```python3
    hessians = tf.map_fn(
        fn=hessian,
        elems=(X_t, size_factors_t, params_t),
        dtype=[dtype],  # hessians of [a, b]
        parallel_iterations=pkg_constants.TF_LOOP_PARALLEL_ITERATIONS
    )
```
There are no between-iteration conditionals in the parallalization of the hessian across genes, right @Hoeze? That would not make sense and I cannot see any but that could be an explanation.
@davidsebfischer Yes, you are right, in theory there cannot be any conditionals between single features

It seems that the collapse to effectively single-threading does not occur if the thread resources of tensorflow are not restricted. The hessian is computed in two loops, an outer loop across data batches and an inner loop across genes. It may be that tensorflow chooses to spend it's threads on prefetching data in the outer loop if few threads are given. Accordingly, the best way to mitigate this would be to not restrict resources (i.e. just limit the resources of the python session) or to get rid of the outer loop. The outer loop is not strictly necessary as all computation are carried out on a gene level, so even samples with millions of cells could be handled here without batching. Thoughts, @Hoeze?
This is really a strong argument for session resource restriction tools, but it would still be nice if we could avoid these as they might interfere with other tools.

I think that getting rid of the outer loop might provide speed advantages in any case as it would reduce the number of operations by increasing the tensor size within each operations, that should be faster.

The Problem is that CSR matrices cannot be easily sliced per gene.
So, basically you are right but only in case of equal row and column slicing performance
Mhm ok, I was just thinking that an iterator over genes would be the best alternative to the two loops but yes the slicing is indeed an issue. mhm..
We could disable prefectching for the iterator of the hessian to try force the threads to be used in the inner loop?

Yes, we could try this.
However, I don't think that this will solve that problem...
Without sparse data, the prefetching should be mainly idling I think
